argument:
Should they be arrested? No, but there should definately be a huge fine!! I am a Firefighter/Paramedic and I drive Code 3 (lights and sirens) all the time.  The most dangerous part of my job is just getting to the emergency through all the traffic.  You'd be surprised at the amount of cars that don't pull over right away.  The idiots who don't pull over are usually on the phone, too occupied to pay attention to their surroundings.  Hands free phones don't help that much either.  You can have a conversation in your car with a passenger without much trouble because they can see what's going on with traffic too and sometimes can even point things out for the driver.  The person on the other end of the phone is just a distraction for the driver and offers no help at all.
PS. Guess what is becoming the biggest excuse/cause for traffice accidents?  Answer: I was on my cell phone and didn't see it coming.
topic: Do you think that people who drive while talking on cell phones should be arrested?
neutralized_formal: Should drivers using cell phones be arrested? I would argue not, but a substantial fine should certainly be imposed. As a Firefighter/Paramedic who frequently drives under Code 3 (lights and sirens), I can attest that navigating through traffic to reach an emergency is often the most perilous part of my job. It's astonishing how many vehicles fail to yield promptly. Often, these drivers are engrossed in phone conversations, oblivious to their surroundings. Even hands-free devices don't significantly mitigate this issue. A passenger in the car can participate in a conversation without causing much distraction, as they can observe the traffic and occasionally assist the driver. However, a person on the other end of a phone call only serves as a distraction, providing no assistance whatsoever. Interestingly, the most common excuse or cause cited for traffic accidents is now: 'I was on my cell phone and didn't see it coming.'

argument:
When considering any changes to the structures of any of their professional leagues, a lot of arguments revolve around how parity can best be maintained or enhanced.

I don't see why anybody cares.
The most exciting moments and periods in sports happen when there's a handful of titans ducking it out, not a mediocre field where anybody can win.

Sure, Barcelona/Real Madrid/Atletico Madrid are miles ahead of most of their competition in La Liga. But tons of people who otherwise would never watch a match will tune in when they face each other.

People don't tune in to watch games between two middle-of-the-pack teams nearly as much as they do for games between the top two teams in probably any sport.
True parity, if achieved, would mean that every team is a middle-of-the-pack team.

Why should I prefer that than having a handful of teams that are truly great and exciting to watch?
topic: Cmv: the us' obsession with 'parity' in sports is misguided.
neutralized_formal: In discussions about potential changes to the structures of professional leagues, the concept of maintaining or enhancing parity often takes center stage. However, the importance of this concept is not universally agreed upon. Some of the most thrilling moments in sports occur when a few dominant teams compete, rather than a balanced field where any team could potentially win. For instance, teams like Barcelona, Real Madrid, and Atletico Madrid are significantly superior to most of their competition in La Liga, yet their matches attract viewers who might not typically watch a game. Similarly, matches between top-tier teams in any sport tend to draw more viewers than those between average teams. If true parity were achieved, every team would be average. The question then arises: why should one prefer this over a scenario where a few teams are truly exceptional and exhilarating to watch?
